tit.cmt: タイトルですので、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: イザナミ（伊弉冉、伊邪那美、伊弉弥）は、日本神話の神。
sen.e: Izanami (represented as 伊弉冉, 伊邪那美, 伊弉弥) is one of gods in Japanese Mythology.
Izanami (written as 伊弉冉, 伊邪那美, 伊弉弥) is a goddess in Japanese mythology.
Izanami (written as 伊弉冉, 伊邪那美, 伊弉弥) is a goddess in Japanese mythology.

sen.j: 文中に「妹伊邪那美」の記述があるためイザナギの妹であると誤解される。
sen.e: Because of the description of '妹伊邪那美' (imoto Izanami) found in some document, she may be misinterpreted as a younger sister of Izanagi (The Male Who Invites).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Because she is described as 'imoto (literally 'younger sister') Izanami' in some documents, she may be misinterpreted as a younger sister of Izanagi (The Male Who Invites).
Because she is described as 'imoto (literally 'younger sister') Izanami' in some documents, she may be misinterpreted as a younger sister of Izanagi.
sen.cmt: イザナギの補足は削除しました。

sen.j: しかし、この場合の「妹」は妻や年下の女性を親しみを込めて使う言葉であった。
sen.e: However, in this case, a wife or girl younger than oneself was affectionately-called as '妹' (imoto).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in this case, 'imoto' affectionately referred to a wife or girl younger than oneself.
However, in this case, 'imoto' affectionately referred to a wife or girl younger than oneself.

sen.j: 自分より年下の女子の兄弟の意味ではない。
sen.e: 妹' (imoto) does not mean a sibling or younger sister.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It does not mean younger sister here.
It does not mean younger sister here.

sen.j: イザナギの妻。
sen.e: Wife of Izanagi (The Male Who Invites)
She was the wife of Izanagi (The Male Who Invites)
She was the wife of Izanagi.
sen.cmt: イザナギの補足は削除しました。

sen.j: 別名 黄泉津大神、道敷大神。
sen.e: Another name, Yomotsu-okami, Chishiki-no-okami
She is also known as Yomotsu-okami and Chishiki-no-okami
She is also known as Yomotsu Okami and Chishiki no Okami.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを削除し、Okami としました。

sen.j: 天地開闢 (日本神話)において神世七代の最後にイザナギとともに生まれた。
sen.e: In creation of heaven and earth (Japanese Mythology), in the last generation of Kaminoyonanayo (seven generations of the gods' world, The Primordial Seven), Izanami was born together with Izanagi.
In the creation of heaven and earth, Izanami and Izanagi were the last generation of Kaminoyonanayo (seven generations of gods).
In the creation of heaven and earth, Izanami and Izanagi were the last generation of Kaminoyonanayo (seven generations of gods).

sen.j: 国産み・神産みにおいてイザナギとの間に日本国土を形づくる多数の子を設ける。
sen.e: In kuni-umi (the birth of (the land) of Japan) and kamiumi (bearing gods between Izanagi and Izanami), Izanami together with Izanagi had a lot of children which formed the land of Japan.
Izanami and Izanagi had a lot of children who formed the land of Japan.
Izanami and Izanagi had a lot of children who formed the land of Japan.

sen.j: その中には淡路島・隠岐島からはじめやがて日本列島を生み、更に山・海など森羅万象の神々を生んだ。
sen.e: They created the Japanese Islands starting from Awaji-shima Island and Oki no shima Island, and then created various gods of shinrabansho (all things in nature, the whole creation) including mountain god and sea god.
They created the Japanese Islands starting with Awaji-shima Island and Oki no shima Island, and then created the various gods of nature, including the mountain god and sea god.
They created the Japanese Islands starting with Awaji-shima Island and Oki no shima Island, and then created the various gods of nature, including the mountain god and sea god.

sen.j: 火の神カグツチを産んだために女性器に熱傷を負って病に臥せのちに亡くなる。
sen.e: When Izanami had Kagutsuchi (kami of fire), she burned her female genitalia with boiling water, got sick, and eventually died.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When Izanami gave birth to Kagutsuchi (the god of fire), she burned her genitalia, got sick, and eventually died.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - I don't know wher 'boiling water'came from, unless the translator confused 湯 and 傷
sen.e: When Izanami gave birth to Kagutsuchi (the god of fire), she burned her genitalia, got sick, and eventually died.

sen.j: しかし、その際にも尿や糞や吐瀉物から神々を生んだ。
sen.e: Even after her death, gods were created from her urine, stool, vomit.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Even after her death, gods were created from her urine, faeces and vomit.
sen.cmt: "stool"→"faeces" - 'stool' is OK but might cause confusion Conjunction
sen.e: Even after her death, gods were created from her urine, faeces and vomit.

sen.j: なきがらは、『古事記』によれば出雲国と伯伎（伯耆国）の境の比婆山（現在の島根県安来市伯太町）に、『日本書紀』の一書によれば紀伊国の熊野の有馬村（三重県熊野市有馬の花窟神社）に葬られたという。
sen.e: Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) says that her body was buried in Hibanoyama Mountain (currently, Hakuta-cho, Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture) located in the border between Izumo Province and Hahaki (Hoki Province), while an "alternate writing" transmitted by "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) says that her body was buried in Arima-mura, Kumano, Kii Province (Hananoiwaya-jinja Shrine in Arima, Kumano City, Mie Prefecture).

The "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) says that her body was buried in Hibanoyama Mountain (currently, Hakuta-cho, Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture), located on the border between Izumo Province and Hahaki (Hoki Province), while an addendum to the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) says that her body was buried in Arima-mura, Kumano, Kii Province (Hananoiwaya-jinja Shrine in Arima, Kumano City, Mie Prefecture).

The "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) says that her body was buried in Hibanoyama Mountain (currently, Hakuta-cho, Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture), located on the border between Izumo Province and Hahaki (Hoki Province), while an addendum to the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) says that her body was buried in Arima-mura, Kumano, Kii Province (Hananoiwaya-jinja Shrine in Arima, Kumano City, Mie Prefecture).

sen.j: 死後、イザナミは、自分に逢いに黄泉国までやってきたイザナギに腐敗した死体を見られたことを恥じ、恐怖で逃げるイザナギを追いかける。
sen.e: Izanami was shamed of her decomposed body seen by Izanagi who came up to yominokuni (hades, realm of the dead, the next world) to see her, and then chased Izanagi when he run away from fear.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Izanagi went to Yominokuni (the realm of the dead) to see Izanami but when he saw her decomposed body, Izanami was ashamed and chased Izanagi, who had fled in terror.
Izanagi went to Yominokuni (the realm of the dead) to see Izanami but when he saw her decomposed body, Izanami was ashamed and chased Izanagi, who had fled in terror.

sen.j: しかし、イザナミに対してイザナギが黄泉国と地上の境である黄泉比良坂（よもつひらさか）で道を塞ぎ、会えなくしてしまう。
sen.e: However, Izanagi blocked a road at the Yomotsu Hirasaka (the slope that leads to the land of the dead) which is the border between the land of the dead and the ground-land so that they would not see each other again.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, Izanagi blocked the road at the Yomotsu Hirasaka, the slope that forms the border between the land of the dead and the world above, so that they would not see each other again.
However, Izanagi blocked the road at the Yomotsu Hirasaka, the slope that forms the border between the land of the dead and the world above, so that they would not see each other again.

sen.j: そして、イザナミとイザナギは離縁した。
sen.e: Then, Izanami and Izanagi got divorced.
Then, Izanami and Izanagi got divorced.
Then, Izanami and Izanagi got divorced.

sen.j: この後、イザナミは黄泉国の主宰神となり、黄泉津大神、道敷大神と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: After that, Izanami became a god presiding yominokuni, and was called Yomotsu-okami or Chishiki-no-okami.
After that, Izanami became the ruling goddess of Yominokuni, and was called Yomotsu-okami or Chishiki-no-okami.
After that, Izanami became the ruling goddess of Yominokuni, and was called Yomotsu Okami or Chishiki no Okami.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを削除し、Okami としました。

sen.j: 名前の「いざな」は「誘う（いざなう）」の意で、「み」は女性を表す語である。
sen.e: Of Izanami, 'Izana' means izanau (invite), and 'me' represents a female.
The 'Izana' part of her name comes from 'izanau' (invite), and 'mi' signifies a female.
The 'Izana' part of her name comes from 'izanau' (invite), and 'mi' signifies a female.

sen.j: また、イザ・ナミ（波）と解してイザ・ナギ（凪）と対の神名であるとする説もある。
sen.e: There is also another theory that Izanami (wave) and Izanagi (lull) are paired.
There is also another theory that Izanami ('nami' means wave) and Izanagi ('nagi' means lull) are paired.
There is also another theory that Izanami ('nami' means wave) and Izanagi ('nagi' means lull) are paired.

sen.j: 別名の黄泉津大神は黄泉国の主宰神の意味である。
sen.e: Another name, Yomotsu-okami means a god presiding yominokuni.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: One of her other names, Yomotsu-okami, means the deity presiding over Yominokuni.
One of her other names, Yomotsu Okami, means the deity presiding over Yominokuni.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを削除し、Okami としました。

sen.j: 道敷大神は（黄泉比良坂でイザナギに）追いついた神という意味である。
sen.e: Chishiki-no-okami means a god who caught up with Izanagi at Yomotsu Hirasaka (the slope that leads to the land of the dead).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Chishiki-no-okami means the god who caught up with Izanagi at Yomotsu Hirasaka.
Chishiki no Okami means the god who caught up with Izanagi at Yomotsu Hirasaka.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを削除し、Okami としました。

sen.j: このような死と戦争をつかさどる性格が黄泉津大神からは読み取れる。
sen.e: Name, Yomotsu-okami implies one who controls death and war.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The name Yomotsu-okami implies one who controls death and war.
The name Yomotsu Okami implies one who controls death and war.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを削除し、Okami としました。

sen.j: 比較神話学的にはハイヌウェレ型神話などに関係付けられる。
sen.e: In terms of comparative mythology, Yomotsu-okami is related to Hainuwele myth.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In terms of comparative mythology, Yomotsu-okami is related to the Hainuwele myth of Seram, Indonesia.
sen.cmt: Added where Hainuwele comes from for clarity
sen.e: In terms of comparative mythology, Yomotsu Okami is related to the Hainuwele myth of Seram, Indonesia.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを削除し、Okami としました。

sen.j: 神陵・神社など
sen.e: Mausoleum of god, shrine
Mausoleums, shrines
Mausoleums, shrines

sen.j: 出雲という地名は日本国母神である、イザナミの美称、稜威母（イズモ）からきたという説もある。
sen.e: There is a theory that the place name, 出雲 (Izumo) came from 稜威母 (Izumo) which was the eulogistic name of Izanami, mother god of Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There is a theory that the place name Izumo (出雲) is derived from Izumo (稜威母), which was the eulogistic name of Izanami, mother god of Japan.
There is a theory that the place name Izumo (出雲) is derived from Izumo (稜威母), which was the eulogistic name of Izanami, mother god of Japan.

sen.j: 出雲国の東側に隣接していた伯耆国は古代には伯伎（ハハキ母の港）と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Hoki Province adjacent to the eastern part of Izumo Province was called Hahaki (which means haha-no-minato, that is, mother's port) in ancient times.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Hoki Province, adjacent to the eastern part of Izumo Province, was called Hahaki (which mean 'mother's port') in ancient times.
Hoki Province, adjacent to the eastern part of Izumo Province, was called Hahaki (which mean 'mother's port') in ancient times.

sen.j: 出雲の神陵在地(島根県安来市伯太町)は江戸時代には松江藩母里藩（＝母の里）とよばれていた。
sen.e: Location of mausoleum of god in Izumo (Hakuta-cho, Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture) was called Mori clan, branch clan of Matsue clan (which means haha-no-sato, that is, village of mother) in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Edo period, the area where the Izumo mausoleum of the gods is located (Hakuta-cho, Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture) was known as Mori Domain (written with characters meaning 'mother's village'), a sub-domain of Matsue Domain.

In the Edo period, the area where the Izumo mausoleum of the gods is located (Hakuta-cho, Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture) was known as Mori Domain (written with characters meaning 'mother's village'), a sub-domain of Matsue Domain.

sen.j: また『出雲国風土記』の意宇郡安来郷はイザナミの息子スサノオが安来と名づけたという逸話が伝わっている。
sen.e: There is an anecdote that Yasugi-go, Ou-gun in "Izumo no kuni fudoki" (topography of Izumo Province) was named by Susanoo who was a son of Izanami.
There is an anecdote in "Izumo no kuni fudoki" (Records of the Culture and Geography of Izumo Province) that Yasugi-go, Ou-gun was named by Izanami's son, Susanoo.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarityRevised translation of "Izumo no kuni fudoki"
sen.e: There is an anecdote in "Izumo no kuni fudoki" (Records of the Culture and Geography of Izumo Province) that Yasugi-go, Ou-gun was named by Izanami's son, Susanoo.

sen.j: また安来市の隣、八束郡東出雲町の揖屋神社付近にはイザナミとイザナギとが永遠の離別をした黄泉平坂の神蹟がある。
sen.e: There is the sacred site of Yomotsu Hirasaka (slope that leads to the land of the dead, and where Izanagi left Izanami for good) which was located near Iya-jinja Shrine in Higashi izumo Town, Yatsuka County next to Yasugi City.
The sacred site of Yomotsu Hirasaka, where Izanagi left Izanami for good, is located near Iya-jinja Shrine in Higashi Izumo Town, Yatsuka County next to Yasugi City.
The sacred site of Yomotsu Hirasaka, where Izanagi left Izanami for good, is located near Iya-jinja Shrine in Higashi-izumo-cho, Yatsuka-gun next to Yasugi City.
sen.cmt: 地名表記を修正しました。

sen.j: 万物を生み出す神、創造神、海の神、製鉄の神として信仰されている。
sen.e: Izanami is worshipped as the god who created all things in the universe, the Creator, the sea god, or the iron-making-god.
Izanami is worshipped as the goddess who created all things in the universe, the Creator, the sea goddess, and the goddess of iron making.
Izanami is worshipped as the goddess who created all things in the universe, the Creator, the sea goddess, and the goddess of iron making.

sen.j: 上記の神陵のほか、以下の神社などで祀られている。
sen.e: Other than the above-described sacred site, Izanami was enshrined at various places including the following shrines:
Other than the above-described sacred sites, srines where Izanami is enshrined include:
Other than the above-described sacred sites, shrines where Izanami is enshrined include the following:
sen.cmt: 原文（和文）を修正し、英文も追加しました。

sen.j: 伊弉諾神宮（兵庫県淡路市）
sen.e: Izanagi-Jingu Shrine (Awaji City Hyogo Prefecture)
Izanagi-Jingu Shrine (Awaji City, Hyogo Prefecture)
Izanagi-Jingu Shrine (Awaji City, Hyogo Prefecture)

sen.j: 多賀大社（滋賀県犬上郡多賀町）
sen.e: Taga Taisha Shrine (Taga-cho, Inugami-gun, Shiga Prefecture)
Taga Taisha Shrine (Taga-cho, Inugami-gun, Shiga Prefecture)
Taga Taisha Shrine (Taga-cho, Inugami-gun, Shiga Prefecture)

sen.j: 皇大神宮別宮の月讀宮（三重県伊勢市）
sen.e: Tsukiyominomiya in Kotai jingu betsugu (Ise City, Mie Prefecture)
Tsukiyominomiya-in, Kotai-jingu Betsugu (Ise City, Mie Prefecture)
Tsukiyominomiya, located in Kotai-jingu Betsugu (Ise City, Mie Prefecture)

sen.j: 花窟神社 (三重県熊野市)
sen.e: Hananoiwaya-jinja Shrine (Kumano City, Mie Prefecture)
Hananoiwaya-jinja Shrine (Kumano City, Mie Prefecture)
Hananoiwaya-jinja Shrine (Kumano City, Mie Prefecture)

sen.j: 三峯神社（埼玉県秩父市）
sen.e: Mitsumine-jinja shrine (Chichibu City Saitama Prefecture)
Mitsumine-jinja shrine (Chichibu City, Saitama Prefecture)
Mitsumine-jinja shrine (Chichibu City, Saitama Prefecture)

sen.j: 筑波山神社（茨城県つくば市）
sen.e: Tsukubasan-jinja Shrine (Tsukuba City, Ibaraki Prefecture)
Tsukubasan-jinja Shrine (Tsukuba City, Ibaraki Prefecture)
Tsukubasan-jinja Shrine (Tsukuba City, Ibaraki Prefecture)

sen.j: 熊野神社 (四街道市亀崎)（千葉県四街道市）
sen.e: Kumano-jinja Shrine (Kamezaki, Yotsukaido City) (Yotsukaido City, Chiba Prefecture)
Kumano-jinja Shrine (Kamezaki, Yotsukaido City) (Yotsukaido City, Chiba Prefecture)

sen.j: 熊野大社（島根県松江市）
sen.e: Kumano Taisha Shrine (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture)
Kumano Taisha Shrine (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture)
Kumano Taisha Shrine (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture)

sen.j: 神魂神社（島根県松江市）
sen.e: Kamosu-jinja Shrine (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture)
Kamosu-jinja Shrine (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture)

sen.j: 山狭神社（島根県安来市）
sen.e: Yamasa-jinja Shrine (Yasuki City, Shimane Prefecture)
Yamasa-jinja Shrine (Yasuki City, Shimane Prefecture)
Yamasa-jinja Shrine (Yasuki City, Shimane Prefecture)

sen.j: 揖夜神社（島根県東出雲町）
sen.e: Iya-jinja Shrine (Higashi izumo Town, Shimane Prefecture)
Iya-jinja Shrine (Higashi izumo Town, Shimane Prefecture)

sen.cmt: 住所表記を変更しました。

sen.j: 佐太神社（島根県松江市）
sen.e: Sada-jinja Shrine (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture)
Sada-jinja Shrine (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture)
Sada-jinja Shrine (Matsue City, Shimane Prefecture)

sen.j: イザナミの墓所の伝承地は、日本神話に記される比婆山や熊野市有馬のほか、雲伯国境を中心として日本各地にある。
sen.e: Besides Hibanoyama Mountain or Arima, Kumano City, there are numerous places where Izanami is said to be buried, throughout Japan, especially around Unpaku (Izumo, Hoki) provincial boarder area.
Besides Hibanoyama Mountain and Arima, Kumano City, there are numerous places throughout Japan where Izanami is said to be buried, especially around the border between Izumo and Hoki.

Besides Hibanoyama Mountain and Arima, Kumano City which are described in Nihonshoki, there are numerous places throughout Japan where Izanami is said to be buried, especially around the border between Izumo and Hoki.

sen.j: 宮内省は八雲村 (島根県)（現 松江市）の神納山を比定地の中で最も有力として「陵墓参考地」に認定している。
sen.e: Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) recognizes Kanna-yama Mountain located in Yakumo-mura (Shimane Prefecture) (currently Matsue City) as a 'referable mausoleum' assuming that the mountain was most-likely presumed location.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Ministry of the Imperial Household recognized Kanna-yama Mountain in Yakumo-mura (present-day Matsue City in Shimane Prefecture) as a 'referable mausoleum', assuming it to be the most-likely site.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarityTense - I presume this should be past as "宮内省" was the name of the ministry until 1947
sen.e: The Ministry of the Imperial Household recognized Mt. Kanna in Yakumo-mura (present-day Matsue City in Shimane Prefecture) as a 'referable mausoleum,' assuming it to be the most-likely site.

sen.j: 内務省 (日本)は船通山の北にある御墓山を「伊弉冉尊御陵流伝地」に指定している。
sen.e: Prewar Ministry of Home Affairs designated Mihaka-yama Mountain located in the north of Mt. Sentsu as a 'place said to be the mausoleum of Izanami-no-mikoto in legend.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The former Ministry of Home Affairs designated Mihaka-yama Mountain located in the north of Mt. Sentsu as a 'place said to be the legendary mausoleum of Izanami-no-mikoto'.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - "prewar" sounds like in the immediaate pre-war period
sen.e: The former Ministry of Home Affairs (Japan) designated Mt. Mihaka located in the north of Mt. Sentsu as a 'place said to be the legendary mausoleum of Izanami no Mikoto.'
sen.cmt: Mt. Mihaka としました。(Japan) を追加しました。

sen.j: しかし、近世以降、古事記解読に初めて成功した本居宣長の古事記伝の話と、鉄製品を作る最良の砂鉄の産地ここ雲伯国境地帯であることから、島根県安来市伯太町のものが支持されていた歴史があり、母里藩の古地図にも峯山大権現と記されているのが確認されている。
sen.e: However, after the early-modern times, because of the description of Kojikiden or Commentaries on the Kojiki written by Norinaga MOTOORI who successfully interpreted Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) for the first time, and the fact that the Unpaku (Izumo, Hoki) provincial boarder area is the best iron sand producing area to make ironware, Hakuta-cho, Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture was once supported, and it is also confirmed that Mineyama-daigongen is on the old map of the domain of Mori.

However, from the 19th century, because of Norinaga MOTOORI's "Kojikiden", or 'Commentaries on the Kojiki', which successfully interpreted the "Kojiki" for the first time, and the fact that the Izumo-Hoki provincial boarder area produces the best iron sand for making ironware, Hakuta-cho in Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture was once supported as the likely site, further supported by the confirmation that Mineyama-daigongen appears on an old map of Mori Domain.
sen.cmt: *Although "近世" means 'modern times', I think the phrase would have a different nuance for non-Japanese speakersRevised for clarity
sen.e: However, from the 19th century, because of Norinaga MOTOORI's "Kojikiden" (Commentaries on the Kojiki), which successfully interpreted the "Kojiki" for the first time, and the fact that the Izumo-Hoki provincial border area produces the best iron sand for making ironware, Hakuta-cho in Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture was once supported as the likely site, further supported by the confirmation that Mineyama-daigongen appears on an old map of Mori Domain.
sen.cmt: "Kojikiden" (Commentaries on the Kojiki) としました。スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: また、最近では安本美典がこれら諸説を文献学的に比較し、島根/鳥取県境に最も近い安来のものを比定している。
sen.e: Nowadays, Biten YASUMOTO identifies the theory of Yasugi which is the closest to the border between Shimane and Totori prefectures by comparing these theories in terms of philology.
Recently, Biten YASUMOTO, by comparing these theories in terms of philology, has identified it as the Yasugi which is the closest to the border between Shimane and Totori Prefectures.
Recently, Biten YASUMOTO, by comparing these theories in terms of philology, has identified it as the one in Yasugi which is the closest to the border between Shimane and Tottori Prefectures.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。
